questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

Falciparum malaria infects both young and mature erythrocytes. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) seen in RBCs are common and they resemble stereo headphones in appearance. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole. There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. 

Hypnozoites are not present in P. falciparum infection.

The peripheral smear finding of P. falciparum malaria are:

  • Multiple ring form
  • Accole form
  • Absent schizont
  • Banana shaped gametocytes
  • Maurer's dots

questions.text: During your rural posting, a patient presents with a high fever and chills. Malaria is endemic in the area so you order a peripheral smear. While examining the peripheral blood smear, you note that the schizont stage is not seen. Which of the following organisms is implicated here?
questions.solution:
The schizont stage is usually not seen in the peripheral smear of individuals having Plasmodium falciparum malaria.

A mature schizont contains merozoites and hemozoin. This will burst to release merozoites into circulation. The merozoites invade fresh erythrocytes, in which they go through the same process of development called erythrocytic schizogony or merogony.

After the ring form is formed in peripheral blood, the remaining RBC cycle of falciparum occurs in the capillaries of the brain and other internal organs. Hence only the ring form is seen in the peripheral smear.

However, for other Plasmodium species, all erythrocytic stages occur in peripheral blood vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following Plasmodium spp. has the longest incubation period?
questions.solution:
Plasmodium malariae has the longest incubation period of 28 days.

The incubation period is the interval between the infective mosquito bite and the first appearance of clinical symptoms. The average incubation periods for Plasmodium species are:

  • P. vivax: 8-31 days (14 days)
  • P. falciparum: 8-14 days (12 days)
  • P. ovale: 8-31days (14 days)
  • P. malariae: 18-40 days (28 days)

Note: The pre-patent period is the interval between the entry of the parasites into the host and the time when they first become detectable in blood.

questions.text: Which of the following Plasmodium spp. mainly affects the old RBCs?
questions.solution:
Plasmodium malaria mainly affects the old RBCs.

Options A and D- P. vivax and P. ovale infect young RBCs and reticulocytes.

Option B- P. falciparum infects RBCs of all ages.

The degree of parasitization is not heavy for P. vivax and P. malariae while very high intensity of parasitization is seen in infection with P. falciparum.

questions.text: A microbiologist is examining the slide shown in the following image under the microscope. Which of the following is false regarding this?

choices.text: 'B' is used for determining the species
'A' is air dried rapidly and stained with one of the Romanowsky stains
For 'B' to be considered negative, at least 200 oil immersion fields should be examined

questions.solution:
In the given image 'A' is a thin smear and 'B' is a thick smear. The thin smear is used for determining the species, not the thick smear.

The two types of smears are prepared from the peripheral blood are:

  • Thin smear– It is used for detecting the parasites and determining the species. They are air-dried rapidly and stained with Romanowsky stains.
  • Thick smear– It is more sensitive and examined under oil immersion microscope. It is more suitable for the rapid detection of malarial parasites. Species identification is difficult. It is recommended that 200 oil immersion fields should be examined before a thick film is declared negative.

The image below shows the thin and thick smears.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the OPD with high-grade fever, chills, and rigors for the past 3 days.  A peripheral blood smear revealed the following. Which of the following is false regarding the diagnostic methods used to detect the condition he is likely suffering from?

choices.text: Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya stain is used for peripheral smear examination
HRP-2 antigen test is done for detection of P.vivax
Acridine orange dye is used in quantitative buffy coat method
Rapid diagnostic tests have lesser sensitivity than microscopy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the peripheral smear showing ring forms are suggestive of P. falciparum malaria. HRP-2 antigen detection used in rapid diagnostic tests for malaria is specific for P. falciparum.

Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya (JSB) stain is routinely used in India to stain peripheral blood smears for the diagnosis of malaria.

Acridine orange dye is used in the quantitative buffy coat (QBC) method of diagnosis which provides better yield compared to peripheral smears.

Rapid diagnostic tests are based on the detection of antigens using immunochromatographic methods. They are less sensitive than microscopy and also cannot differentiate between species except P. falciparum. The 2 antigens detected are:

  • pLDH (parasite lactate dehydrogenase)- pan malarial antigen
  • HRP-2 (histidine-rich protein 2)- specific for P.falciparum.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a 5-day history of fever is brought to the casualty by his son after an episode of seizures.  He is diagnosed with malignant tertian malaria. Which of the following complications will you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
Metabolic acidosis (and not alkalosis) is a complication of malignant tertain malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

Complications of falciparum malaria include:

  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Cerebral malaria
  • Algid malaria
  • Septicemic malaria
  • Blackwater fever
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute renal failure
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hyperpyrexia
  • Severe anemia
  • Shock

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and weakness for 5 days. He gives a history of blood transfusion 4 months back. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the microscopy showing Maltese crosses or tetrads are suggestive of babesiosis caused by Babesia microti.

The definitive host for babesia are ixodid ticks. Man is an incidental, dead-end host.

On microscopic examination, babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit which differentiates it from P. falciparum.

Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/Maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.

The below image shows Maltese cross appearance of Babesia microti.

questions.text: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for diagnosis of which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. 

It is based on the principle that the presence of anti-toxoplasma antibodies in the patient's serum inhibits the staining of trophozoites by alkaline methylene blue dye. 

Toxoplasma trophozoites and complement are added to the patient's serum which is then incubated for an hour at 37°C. After incubation, methylene blue dye is added.

If anti-toxoplasma antibodies are present in the serum, these are activated by complement and the parasite membrane is lysed. Thus, the trophozoites are not stained (positive result).

If there are no antibodies, trophozoites will take up the stain and appear blue under the microscope. This is considered to be a negative result.

The dilution of the test serum at which 50% of the tachyzoites are not stained is reported as the antibody titer of the test serum. The test is highly sensitive and specific.

It cannot differentiate between recent or past infections as it detects only IgG antibodies.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Toxoplasma gondii?

choices.text: Oocysts are formed within the intermediate host
The tachyzoites inside the tissue cyst can be reactivated on immunosuppression

questions.solution:
Human toxoplasmosis is a zoonosis. It is transmitted by cats.

Toxoplasma gondii has two types of life cycles:

  • Enteric cycle
  • Exoenteric cycle

The enteric cycle occurs in definitive hosts such as cats. Exoenteric cycle occurs in intermediate hosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc.

Both asexual reproduction (schizogony) and sexual reproduction (gametogony) occur within the mucosal epithelial cells of the small intestine of the cat. The tachyzoites and tissue cyst represent stages in asexual multiplication, while the oocyst is formed by sexual reproduction.

All three forms, tachyzoites, tissue cyst, and oocyst occur in the definitive host. Only the asexual forms, tachyzoites, and tissue cysts are present in the intermediate host.

Tachyzoites continue to multiply and spread locally by the lymphatic system and blood, while the bradyzoites multiply slowly inside the tissue cyst. The dormant bradyzoites inside the cyst may be reactivated on immune suppression causing renewed infection in the host.

The below image shows the life cycle of Toxoplasma gondii.

questions.text: An HIV positive pregnant woman was brought to the ER after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. CECT was done which showed multiple enhancing lesions. A stereotactic biopsy of the cerebral lesions was done and the image is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug for her treatment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils surrounding the toxoplasma bradyzoites which are encased in cysts are suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Spiramycin is the drug of choice during pregnancy.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in HIV +ve patients and usually occurs when CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.

It appears as ring enhancing lesions on contrast enhanced CT. Calcification may also be seen in old lesions.

Sabin-Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against toxoplasma. IIF (indirect immunofluorescence), IHA (indirect heamagglutination), and CFT (complement fixation test) are also used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. Dye test remains positive throughout life, while CFT becomes negative soon after acute infection.

ELISA is most commonly used and IgM and IgG antibodies are estimated separately.

Standard treatment is sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. The drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy is spiramycin.

questions.text: A Kinyoun-positive oocyst (25 μm) isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea is shown in the image. What is the likely organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. Kinyoun-positive oocysts with the size of 25 μm in the image are formed by Cystoisospora.

questions.text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago came with complaints of diarrhea for the last 9 days. The stool sample subjected to Kinyoun staining revealed 4-6 µm structures as shown below. Which of the following is true about the causative organism?

choices.text: It is an obligate intracellular organism
Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool
Metronidazole is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with Kinyoun stain positive oocysts of size 4-6 µm is suggestive of cryptosporidiosis. The oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool. 

Cryptosporidium is a coccidian parasite and implicated in causing traveler's diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The two cryptosporidium species responsible are C. hominis and C. parvum. 

The infective form is the oocyst excreted in the patient's feces, which can be acquired through drinking or during recreational water activities. The oocysts are immediately infectious (unlike isospora oocysts, which require maturation), and may cause autoinfection or be implicated in person-to-person transmission. Because of their small size (4-5micron), they is difficult to see using routine staining. Hence acid-fast/Kinyoun's stain is used. 

Once ingested, the 4 sporozoites are released from the cyst and attach to the small intestinal mucosa. It causes crampy abdominal pain and non-inflammatory watery diarrhea.

Treatment is mainly supportive, though nitazoxanide has been FDA approved for use in cryptosporidium infection.
